articles.headline: New York Fed Is Criticized on Oversight
articles.snippet: “Is the Federal Reserve up to the task of regulating financial institutions that are so large and complex?” the chairman of a Senate panel asked William C. Dudley.
articles.abstract: “Is the Federal Reserve up to the task of regulating financial institutions that are so large and complex?” the chairman of a Senate panel asked William C. Dudley.
articles.lead_paragraph: The government agency that watches over Wall Street came in for repeated rounds of criticism on Friday at a Senate hearing into its regulatory track record.

articles.headline: Allure of ISIS for Pakistanis Is on the Rise
articles.snippet: The Islamic State is not operating in Pakistan, officials say, but militants are beginning to invoke its name and some are pledging their allegiance.
articles.abstract: The Islamic State is not operating in Pakistan, officials say, but militants are beginning to invoke its name and some are pledging their allegiance.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Across Pakistan, the black standard of the Islamic State has been popping up all over.

articles.headline: As Immigration Rules Shift, Migrants’ Joy Is Tempered
articles.snippet: Some expressed confusion about how they would obtain the new documents that would allow them to obtain work permits under the president’s plan. And immigrants who came here legally expressed betrayal.
articles.abstract: Some expressed confusion about how they would obtain the new documents that would allow them to obtain work permits under the president’s plan. And immigrants who came here legally expressed betrayal.
articles.lead_paragraph: HYATTSVILLE, Md. — For 14 years, José Alberto Piña, a Mexican immigrant without legal papers, worked on the same landscaping crew at a Maryland golf course. It was outdoor work, running sprinklers, mowing and trimming. He liked it, Mr. Piña said, and his boss liked him.

articles.headline: Yangon’s Hero, Wielding Power of Stop and Go
articles.snippet: As liberalization swamps Myanmar’s largest city with cars, a young police sergeant adept at managing the flow has been winning praise — and quite a few tips.
articles.abstract: As liberalization swamps Myanmar’s largest city with cars, a young police sergeant adept at managing the flow has been winning praise — and quite a few tips.
articles.lead_paragraph: YANGON, Myanmar — For 12 hours nearly every day, Sgt. Khin Myint Maung stands in one of the most chaotic intersections in this chronically gridlocked city, untangling traffic snarls with patience and unflagging good humor.

articles.headline: Comparing College Costs the Easy Way
articles.snippet: College Abacus aggregates cost calculations from up to three colleges at a time on its own website, but is blocked by some institutions.
articles.abstract: College Abacus aggregates cost calculations from up to three colleges at a time on its own website, but is blocked by some institutions.
articles.lead_paragraph: If you’re a shoestring start-up trying to get noticed in an enormous industry, there’s nothing that helps more than having big players try to ban you. But from financial services to airlines, the pattern repeats itself again and again, as the lumbering giants seek to destroy rather than cooperate.

articles.headline: In a Shift, Obama Extends U.S. Role in Afghan Combat
articles.snippet: President Obama’s order would allow American forces to carry out missions against the Taliban and other militant groups threatening American troops or the Afghan government, sources said.
articles.abstract: President Obama’s order would allow American forces to carry out missions against the Taliban and other militant groups threatening American troops or the Afghan government, sources said.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama decided in recent weeks to authorize a more expansive mission for the military in Afghanistan in 2015 than originally planned, a move that ensures American troops will have a direct role in fighting in the war-ravaged country for at least another year.
articles.byline: By Mark Mazzetti and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: This Time, the Protesters in Ferguson May Decide to Pass
articles.snippet: Some former protesters said they were unsure if they would again join the demonstrations that are expected after a grand jury decides whether to indict Darren Wilson, a white police officer, for killing Michael Brown, 18.
articles.abstract: Some former protesters said they were unsure if they would again join the demonstrations that are expected after a grand jury decides whether to indict Darren Wilson, a white police officer, for killing Michael Brown, 18.
articles.lead_paragraph: FERGUSON, Mo. — When protests broke out here after the police shooting of an unarmed black teenager in August, James Bass knew he had to hit the streets. His father lived in Ferguson, he lived close by, and like many young black men in the St. Louis area, Mr. Bass wanted his voice to be heard.

articles.headline: G.M. ‘Bullied’ Manufacturer Over Poorly Designed Part, Email Says
articles.snippet: The email between employees of Delphi, the manufacturer, discussed pressure from a G.M. engineer over an ignition switch that is linked to at least 33 deaths.
articles.abstract: The email between employees of Delphi, the manufacturer, discussed pressure from a G.M. engineer over an ignition switch that is linked to at least 33 deaths.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT — General Motors pressured a supplier to continue producing a substandard ignition switch a decade ago and leaned on the company to improve it even though it could not be fixed, a newly disclosed email shows.

articles.headline: The Week That Shook the Fed
articles.snippet: For a secretive institution, assorted challenges to how it uses its power. Or doesn’t.
articles.abstract: For a secretive institution, assorted challenges to how it uses its power. Or doesn’t.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Federal Reserve Board prefers to operate in a shroud of secrecy, and its officials really don’t like having to answer to anybody.

articles.headline: At Spain’s Door, a Welcome Mat for Entrepreneurs
articles.snippet: A nation is beckoning foreign brains and money with the kind of immigration reform that Silicon Valley can only envy.
articles.abstract: A nation is beckoning foreign brains and money with the kind of immigration reform that Silicon Valley can only envy.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last year, after more than a decade in Silicon Valley, Stacia Carr helped sell the company she was running and went looking for a change of pace.

articles.headline: The Fight for $15.37 an Hour
articles.snippet: Forces both inside and outside the traditional labor movement united to campaign for a higher minimum wage for hotel workers in Los Angeles.
articles.abstract: Forces both inside and outside the traditional labor movement united to campaign for a higher minimum wage for hotel workers in Los Angeles.
articles.lead_paragraph: Most Sunday mornings last summer, Julia Gould set up a table at the Hollywood Farmers Market. Alongside stalls selling shiitake mushrooms, free-range poultry and orange-blossom honey, she was selling an idea: a $15.37-an-hour minimum wage for the city’s hotel workers — more than twice the federal minimum wage and one of the highest minimum wages in the nation.

articles.headline: Hour’s Drive Outside Kabul, Taliban Reign
articles.snippet: In the absence of international troops or their air support, the Taliban have eclipsed the legitimacy of government forces in several parts of Afghanistan.
articles.abstract: In the absence of international troops or their air support, the Taliban have eclipsed the legitimacy of government forces in several parts of Afghanistan.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHARKALAH, Afghanistan — The explosion ripped through the floor of the Humvee, tearing a hole in the armored vehicle and injuring the district governor. The crack of Taliban gunfire followed.

articles.headline: In Iran Talks, U.S. Seeks to Prevent a Covert Weapon
articles.snippet: Unstated during negotiations is the fear of a “sneakout,” the risk of a bomb being produced at an undetected facility, or built from fuel and components obtained from one of Iran’s few trading partners.
articles.abstract: Unstated during negotiations is the fear of a “sneakout,” the risk of a bomb being produced at an undetected facility, or built from fuel and components obtained from one of Iran’s few trading partners.
articles.lead_paragraph: VIENNA — Behind the efforts to close a nuclear deal with Iran this weekend lies a delicate question that has been little discussed in public: how to design an agreement to maximize the chances that Western intelligence agencies would catch any effort to develop an atomic bomb at a covert site.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger and William J. Broad

articles.headline: Bidding in Government Auction of Airwaves Reaches $34 Billion
articles.snippet: Prices are likely to rise further because the auction has no definite end and could continue for days or weeks.
articles.abstract: Prices are likely to rise further because the auction has no definite end and could continue for days or weeks.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A government auction of airwaves for use in mobile broadband has blown through presale estimates, becoming the biggest auction in the Federal Communications Commission’s history and signaling that wireless companies expect demand for Internet access by smartphones to continue to soar.

articles.headline: Turmoil Over Immigration Status? California Has Lived It for Decades
articles.snippet: President Obama’s executive action on immigration was almost anticlimactic to many people in California.
articles.abstract: President Obama’s executive action on immigration was almost anticlimactic to many people in California.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — There may be no better place than California to measure the contradictions, crosswinds and confusion that come with trying to change immigration law.
articles.byline: By Adam Nagourney, Ian Lovett and Vindu Goel

articles.headline: Marion Barry, Washington’s ‘Mayor for Life,’ Even After Prison, Dies at 78
articles.snippet: Mr. Barry was a flamboyant and polarizing mayor of the nation’s capital who went to prison on a cocaine charge and then made one of the most improbable comebacks in the history of American politics.
articles.abstract: Mr. Barry was a flamboyant and polarizing mayor of the nation’s capital who went to prison on a cocaine charge and then made one of the most improbable comebacks in the history of American politics.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Marion S. Barry Jr., a sharecropper’s son and civil rights pioneer who became a flamboyant and polarizing mayor of Washington, went to prison on a cocaine charge and then recaptured City Hall in one of the most improbable comebacks in the history of American politics, died early Sunday in Washington. He was 78.

articles.headline: With ‘Hunger Games’ Campaigns, Lionsgate Punches Above Its Weight
articles.snippet: In its campaigns for the “Hunger Games” films, Lionsgate’s tiny marketing department has used mastery of social media and a culture of risk-taking to dazzle the legacy studios.
articles.abstract: In its campaigns for the “Hunger Games” films, Lionsgate’s tiny marketing department has used mastery of social media and a culture of risk-taking to dazzle the legacy studios.
articles.lead_paragraph: SANTA MONICA, Calif. — With its cutting-edge social-media campaigns for “The Hunger Games,” the tiny 27-person marketing department at Lionsgate has become a model for Hollywood’s legacy studios: scrappy, thrifty, forward-thinking.

articles.headline: Solar and Wind Energy Start to Win on Price vs. Conventional Fuels
articles.snippet: The cost of electricity from wind and solar power plants has plummeted, making it cheaper than coal or natural gas in some places.
articles.abstract: The cost of electricity from wind and solar power plants has plummeted, making it cheaper than coal or natural gas in some places.
articles.lead_paragraph: For the solar and wind industries in the United States, it has been a long-held dream: to produce energy at a cost equal to conventional sources like coal and natural gas.

articles.headline: ‘Serial,’ Podcasting’s First Breakout Hit, Sets Stage for More
articles.snippet: If podcasting’s model seems familiar — Netflix, anyone? — it’s no surprise that it will have similar transformative effects on traditional audio programming providers, like public radio.
articles.abstract: If podcasting’s model seems familiar — Netflix, anyone? — it’s no surprise that it will have similar transformative effects on traditional audio programming providers, like public radio.
articles.lead_paragraph: On Thursday, people will gather around tables everywhere and, well, talk about how bummed they are that “Serial,” the wildly popular podcast, is taking Thanksgiving off.

articles.headline: Graft Hobbles Iraq’s Military in Fighting ISIS
articles.snippet: The Iraqi military and police forces had been so pillaged by their own leadership that they all but collapsed this spring in the face of the advancing Islamic State fighters.
articles.abstract: The Iraqi military and police forces had been so pillaged by their own leadership that they all but collapsed this spring in the face of the advancing Islamic State fighters.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — One Iraqi general is known as “chicken guy” because of his reputation for selling his soldiers’ poultry provisions. Another is “arak guy,” for his habit of enjoying that anise-flavored liquor on the job. A third is named after Iraq’s 10,000-dinar bills, “General Deftar,” and is infamous for selling officer commissions.

articles.headline: Home-Birth Film by Ricki Lake Prepares for Redelivery, Worldwide
articles.snippet: An expanded version of “The Business of Being Born,” a documentary by the actress Ricki Lake that some experts say plays down the risks of delivering babies at home, will debut on Netflix.
articles.abstract: An expanded version of “The Business of Being Born,” a documentary by the actress Ricki Lake that some experts say plays down the risks of delivering babies at home, will debut on Netflix.
articles.lead_paragraph: One of the most talked about and provocative documentaries about childbirth is having its own rebirth.

articles.headline: Uncertainty Upends Lives as Ferguson Awaits Grand Jury Decision
articles.snippet: Schools closed, rumors swirled and businesses felt repercussions as the silence of a grand jury investigating the police killing of Michael Brown upended normal life.
articles.abstract: Schools closed, rumors swirled and businesses felt repercussions as the silence of a grand jury investigating the police killing of Michael Brown upended normal life.
articles.lead_paragraph: FERGUSON, Mo. — At Spencer’s Bakery near the barricaded police station here, there have been fewer Thanksgiving orders, including for pumpkin pie.
articles.byline: By Manny Fernandez and Alan Blinder

articles.headline: Hagel Resigns Under Pressure as Global Crises Test Pentagon
articles.snippet: Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel’s passivity and lack of support in President Obama’s inner circle proved too much for an administration that found itself back on a war footing.
articles.abstract: Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel’s passivity and lack of support in President Obama’s inner circle proved too much for an administration that found itself back on a war footing.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel resigned under pressure on Monday after President Obama determined that he had to shake up his national security team in the face of escalating conflicts overseas and hawkish Republicans reasserting themselves on Capitol Hill.
